expanded_description: Velocity-time graphs plot velocity versus time, providing direct visualization of how an object's velocity changes. These graphs are powerful tools for determining acceleration and calculating displacement, complementing the information from position-time graphs.

core_concept.principle: A velocity-time graph plots velocity (vertical axis) versus time (horizontal axis). The slope of the line equals acceleration, and the area under the curve equals displacement. The graph's shape reveals whether an object is speeding up, slowing down, or moving at constant velocity.
core_concept.explanation: Velocity-time graphs encode different information than position-time graphs. While position-time graphs show where an object is, velocity-time graphs show how fast and in what direction it's moving. The key relationships are: (1) slope = acceleration ($\text{slope} = \Delta v / \Delta t = a$), and (2) area under curve = displacement ($\text{area} = v \times \Delta t = \Delta x$). Horizontal lines indicate constant velocity (uniform motion, zero acceleration). Sloped lines indicate changing velocity (accelerated motion). The steeper the slope, the greater the acceleration. Positive slopes indicate positive acceleration; negative slopes indicate negative acceleration. Understanding velocity-time graphs is essential for analyzing accelerated motion and forms the foundation for solving complex kinematics problems.

sections.introduction: Understanding the structure and components of velocity-time graphs is essential for interpreting motion information correctly.

key_concept.definition: A velocity-time graph has time ($t$) on the horizontal axis and velocity ($v$) on the vertical axis. Each point $(t, v)$ shows the object's velocity at that specific time. The graph directly displays how velocity changes over time.
key_concept.context: Unlike position-time graphs which require calculating slope to find velocity, velocity-time graphs show velocity directly. This makes certain analyses easier, particularly for accelerated motion.

principles.statement: Horizontal axis: time ($t$), typically in seconds. Vertical axis: velocity ($v$), typically in m/s. Both axes must be labeled with units.
principles.application: Check axis labels to identify what's being plotted.
principles.example: Horizontal: Time (s) from 0 to 10. Vertical: Velocity (m/s) from -20 to +40.

principles.statement: The height of the curve at any time gives the velocity at that moment. No calculation needed—just read the value.
principles.application: To find velocity at $t = 3$ s: find 3 on horizontal axis, go up to curve, read across to vertical axis.
principles.example: Point at $(4 \text{ s}, 15 \text{ m/s})$ means: at time $t = 4$ s, velocity is $v = 15$ m/s.

principles.statement: Values above horizontal axis: positive velocity (moving in positive direction). Values below: negative velocity (moving in negative direction). On axis: zero velocity (momentarily at rest).
principles.application: Sign of velocity indicates direction of motion.
principles.example: Line above axis at $v = +10$ m/s: moving in positive direction. Line below axis at $v = -5$ m/s: moving in negative direction.

principles.statement: The slope of a velocity-time graph equals acceleration: $\text{slope} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = a$
principles.example: Slope = $\frac{30 \text{ m/s} - 10 \text{ m/s}}{4 \text{ s} - 0 \text{ s}} = \frac{20 \text{ m/s}}{4 \text{ s}} = 5$ m/s². Acceleration is +5 m/s².

principles.statement: The area between the curve and the horizontal axis equals displacement: $\text{area} = \Delta x$. For rectangles: area = base × height = $\Delta t \times v$.
principles.application: Calculate area under curve to find displacement.
principles.example: Rectangle: width = 5 s, height = 8 m/s. Area = $5 \times 8 = 40$ m. Displacement = 40 m.

examples.explanation: Constant velocity (slope = 0, so acceleration = 0). Uniform motion.
Changing velocity (non-zero slope, so acceleration present). Accelerated motion.
Velocity changing sign—object reverses direction. Goes through $v = 0$ (momentarily stops).
Velocity increasing. Positive acceleration. Speeding up if moving in positive direction, or slowing down if moving in negative direction.
Velocity decreasing. Negative acceleration. Slowing down if moving in positive direction, or speeding up if moving in negative direction.
Steep slope = large acceleration (rapid velocity change). Gentle slope = small acceleration (gradual velocity change).

worked_examples.title: Reading Velocity from Graph
worked_examples.problem: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $v = 12$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 8$ s. (a) What is the velocity at $t = 3$ s? (b) What is the velocity at $t = 7$ s? (c) Describe the motion.

step_by_step.explanation: Read height of line at $t = 3$ s: $v = 12$ m/s
Read height of line at $t = 7$ s: $v = 12$ m/s (same—horizontal line)
Horizontal line at constant positive velocity: uniform motion in positive direction at 12 m/s. No acceleration (slope = 0).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $v = 12$ m/s, (b) $v = 12$ m/s, (c) Uniform motion, constant velocity +12 m/s, zero acceleration
worked_examples.concept_applied: Height of velocity-time graph gives velocity directly. Horizontal line = constant velocity.

image.alt: Labeled velocity-time graph showing axes, slope, and area
image.caption: Velocity-time graph anatomy: time on horizontal axis, velocity on vertical axis, slope = acceleration, area = displacement

sections.introduction: The slope of a velocity-time graph gives acceleration directly—this is the most important relationship for analyzing accelerated motion.

key_concept.definition: Acceleration equals the slope of the velocity-time graph: $a = \text{slope} = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_2 - v_1}{t_2 - t_1}$. For straight lines, slope (acceleration) is constant. For curves, slope varies—find instantaneous slope at a point.
key_concept.context: This relationship makes velocity-time graphs the preferred tool for analyzing acceleration. No separate calculation needed—just find the slope.

principles.statement: Choose two points: $(t_1, v_1)$ and $(t_2, v_2)$. Calculate: $\text{slope} = \frac{v_2 - v_1}{t_2 - t_1}$
principles.application: Use any two points on straight line. For uniform acceleration, slope is constant everywhere.
principles.example: Points: $(2 \text{ s}, 5 \text{ m/s})$ and $(6 \text{ s}, 25 \text{ m/s})$. Slope $= \frac{25 - 5}{6 - 2} = \frac{20}{4} = 5$ m/s².

principles.principle: Sign of Slope = Direction of Acceleration
principles.statement: Positive slope (upward) → positive acceleration (velocity increasing). Negative slope (downward) → negative acceleration (velocity decreasing). Zero slope (horizontal) → zero acceleration (constant velocity).
principles.application: Slope direction immediately shows if accelerating or decelerating.
principles.example: Upward-sloping line: $a > 0$ (positive acceleration). Downward-sloping: $a < 0$ (negative acceleration). Horizontal: $a = 0$ (no acceleration).

principles.principle: Magnitude of Slope = Rate of Velocity Change
principles.statement: Steeper slope = larger acceleration (rapid velocity change). Gentler slope = smaller acceleration (gradual change).
principles.example: Line A: slope = 8 m/s². Line B: slope = 2 m/s². Object A accelerates 4 times faster than B.

principles.statement: Slope has units of (velocity units)/(time units) = acceleration units. Typically m/s².
principles.application: Always include units when calculating acceleration.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Positive Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: A velocity-time graph shows a straight line from $(0 \text{ s}, 0 \text{ m/s})$ to $(6 \text{ s}, 30 \text{ m/s})$. Calculate the acceleration.

step_by_step.explanation: Positive slope → positive acceleration. Velocity increases by 5 m/s every second. Object speeding up in positive direction.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Acceleration = slope of velocity-time graph. Upward slope = positive acceleration.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Negative Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: A graph shows velocity decreasing from $(0 \text{ s}, 40 \text{ m/s})$ to $(8 \text{ s}, 0 \text{ m/s})$. Find the acceleration.

step_by_step.explanation: Negative slope → negative acceleration. Velocity decreases by 5 m/s every second. Object slowing down (was moving in positive direction, coming to rest).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Downward-sloping line has negative slope, indicating negative acceleration (deceleration if moving forward).

worked_examples.title: Zero Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: Between $t = 5$ s and $t = 9$ s, the graph is a horizontal line at $v = 15$ m/s. What is the acceleration during this interval?

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal means velocity not changing. $\Delta v = 0$.
$a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{15 - 15}{9 - 5} = \frac{0}{4}$
Zero slope → zero acceleration → constant velocity → uniform motion.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Horizontal line on v-t graph (slope = 0) means zero acceleration, constant velocity.

worked_examples.title: Multiple Segments with Different Accelerations
worked_examples.problem: A graph has three segments: (1) $t = 0$ to $t = 3$ s: line from $v = 0$ to $v = 15$ m/s, (2) $t = 3$ to $t = 7$ s: horizontal at $v = 15$ m/s, (3) $t = 7$ to $t = 10$ s: line from $v = 15$ m/s to $v = 0$. Find acceleration for each segment.
worked_examples.final_answer: Segment 1: $a = +5$ m/s², Segment 2: $a = 0$ m/s², Segment 3: $a = -5$ m/s²
worked_examples.concept_applied: Different slopes in different segments mean different accelerations. Calculate slope for each segment separately.

image.alt: Diagram showing how to calculate slope to find acceleration
image.caption: Acceleration = slope of v-t graph = rise/run = Δv/Δt

sections.introduction: The area between the velocity-time curve and the horizontal axis equals the displacement during that time interval. This powerful relationship allows finding displacement even for complex motion.

key_concept.definition: Displacement equals the area under the velocity-time curve: $\Delta x = \text{area under curve}$. For simple shapes (rectangles, triangles), use geometry formulas. For complex shapes, break into simpler pieces and sum. Areas above the axis are positive displacement; areas below are negative displacement.
key_concept.context: This area-displacement relationship comes from the definition of velocity: $v = \Delta x / \Delta t$, which rearranges to $\Delta x = v \Delta t$. On a graph, $v \times \Delta t$ is the area of a rectangle with height $v$ and width $\Delta t$.

principles.statement: For any velocity-time graph, the area between the curve and the time axis from $t_1$ to $t_2$ equals the displacement during that interval.
principles.application: Calculate area to find how far the object moved.
principles.example: Rectangular area: width = 5 s, height = 8 m/s. Area = $5 \times 8 = 40$ m. Displacement = 40 m.

principles.statement: Area above horizontal axis (positive velocity) → positive displacement. Area below axis (negative velocity) → negative displacement. Total displacement = sum of signed areas.
principles.application: Keep track of signs when calculating areas.
principles.example: Above axis: area = +30 m (moved 30 m in positive direction). Below axis: area = -20 m (moved 20 m in negative direction). Total: +30 + (-20) = +10 m net displacement.

principles.statement: Rectangle: $A = \text{base} \times \text{height} = \Delta t \times v$. Triangle: $A = \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height} = \frac{1}{2} \Delta t \times \Delta v$. Trapezoid: $A = \frac{1}{2}(b_1 + b_2) \times h$.
principles.example: Horizontal line creates rectangle. Sloped line from zero creates triangle. Combination creates trapezoid.

principles.statement: For complex curves, divide into simpler shapes (rectangles, triangles), calculate each area, sum them.
principles.example: Graph with three segments: rectangle (20 m) + triangle (15 m) + rectangle (-10 m) = 25 m total displacement.

worked_examples.title: Displacement from Rectangular Area
worked_examples.problem: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $v = 12$ m/s from $t = 2$ s to $t = 7$ s. Find the displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line creates rectangle. Base = time interval, height = velocity.
Base = $7 - 2 = 5$ s. Height = $12$ m/s.
Area = displacement. Object moved 60 m in positive direction during this 5-second interval.

worked_examples.concept_applied: For constant velocity (horizontal line), area = rectangle = $\Delta t \times v$.

worked_examples.title: Displacement from Triangular Area
worked_examples.problem: A graph shows velocity increasing linearly from $v = 0$ at $t = 0$ to $v = 20$ m/s at $t = 4$ s. Find displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Line from origin creates right triangle. Base = 4 s, height = 20 m/s.
$\text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$
Displacement = 40 m in positive direction.

worked_examples.concept_applied: For velocity starting from zero and increasing linearly, area = triangle = $\frac{1}{2} \Delta t \times v_{\text{final}}$.

worked_examples.title: Displacement with Negative Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A graph shows constant velocity $v = -6$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 5$ s. Find displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Rectangle below horizontal axis (negative velocity). Base = 5 s, height = 6 m/s (magnitude).
Area magnitude = $5 \times 6 = 30$ m. But below axis → negative.
Negative displacement: moved 30 m in negative direction.

worked_examples.final_answer: $\Delta x = -30$ m (30 m in negative direction)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Area below horizontal axis is negative displacement (motion in negative direction).

worked_examples.title: Trapezoidal Area
worked_examples.problem: Velocity increases from $v_i = 10$ m/s at $t = 0$ to $v_f = 30$ m/s at $t = 4$ s. Find displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: Trapezoid: parallel sides at $v = 10$ m/s (top) and $v = 30$ m/s (bottom), width = 4 s. Or break into rectangle + triangle.
Rectangle: $10 \times 4 = 40$ m. Triangle: $\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times (30-10) = \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 20 = 40$ m. Total: $40 + 40 = 80$ m

worked_examples.concept_applied: Trapezoid area or sum of rectangle + triangle gives displacement for linearly increasing velocity.

worked_examples.title: Multi-Segment Displacement
worked_examples.problem: Graph segments: (1) $v = 0$ to $v = 15$ m/s over 3 s (triangle), (2) constant $v = 15$ m/s for 4 s (rectangle), (3) $v = 15$ m/s to $v = 0$ over 3 s (triangle). Find total displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $A_1 = \frac{1}{2} \times 3 \times 15 = 22.5$ m
$A_3 = \frac{1}{2} \times 3 \times 15 = 22.5$ m

worked_examples.concept_applied: For multi-segment motion, sum areas of all segments to get total displacement.

worked_examples.title: Motion with Direction Reversal
worked_examples.problem: Graph shows: (1) $v = +20$ m/s for 3 s, (2) $v$ decreases to $-10$ m/s over 2 s, (3) $v = -10$ m/s for 2 s. Find (a) displacement for each segment, (b) total displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $A_1 = 3 \times 20 = +60$ m (positive displacement)
From $+20$ to $-10$ over 2 s. Area above axis + area below. Better: trapezoid: $A_2 = \frac{1}{2}(20 + (-10)) \times 2 = \frac{1}{2}(10) \times 2 = +10$ m
$A_3 = 2 \times (-10) = -20$ m (negative displacement)
$\Delta x_{\text{total}} = 60 + 10 + (-20) = 50$ m

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Seg 1: +60 m, Seg 2: +10 m, Seg 3: -20 m. (b) Total: +50 m
worked_examples.concept_applied: When velocity changes sign, keep track of positive and negative areas. Net displacement = algebraic sum.

image.alt: Diagram showing area under v-t curve representing displacement
image.caption: Displacement = area under v-t curve. Rectangle, triangle, or other shape—area gives displacement.

sections.introduction: The shape of a velocity-time graph reveals the type of motion and how acceleration behaves.

key_concept.definition: Horizontal lines indicate constant velocity (uniform motion). Sloped straight lines indicate constant acceleration. Curves indicate changing acceleration. The specific shape provides detailed motion information.
key_concept.context: Recognizing standard graph shapes allows instant identification of motion characteristics.

classifications.behavior: Simplest motion—no forces or balanced forces.

examples.explanation: Positive constant velocity. Moving steadily in positive direction.
Negative constant velocity. Moving steadily in negative direction.
Zero velocity. Object at rest throughout.
Constant positive acceleration. Velocity increasing at steady rate. If starting positive: speeding up. If starting negative: slowing down toward zero.
Constant negative acceleration. Velocity decreasing at steady rate. If starting positive: slowing down. If starting negative: speeding up (in negative direction).
Larger acceleration. Velocity changes more rapidly.
Velocity changes sign—object reverses direction. Passes through $v = 0$.

classifications.behavior: Advanced cases, less common in Grade 9/10.

examples.explanation: Acceleration increasing. Velocity changing faster and faster.
Acceleration decreasing. Velocity change slowing down, approaching constant velocity.

classifications.note: Most Grade 9/10 problems assume constant acceleration (straight lines on v-t graphs).

worked_examples.title: Identifying Motion Types
worked_examples.problem: Describe the motion for each graph: (a) Horizontal line at $v = 8$ m/s, (b) Straight line from $v = 0$ to $v = 20$ m/s over 4 s, (c) Straight line from $v = 30$ m/s to $v = 0$ over 6 s.

step_by_step.explanation: Constant velocity $v = 8$ m/s. Slope = 0, so $a = 0$. Uniform motion in positive direction.
Velocity increasing from 0 to 20 m/s. Slope = $\frac{20-0}{4-0} = 5$ m/s². Constant positive acceleration. Speeding up from rest.
Velocity decreasing from 30 to 0 m/s. Slope = $\frac{0-30}{6-0} = -5$ m/s². Constant negative acceleration. Slowing to stop.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Uniform motion, $v = 8$ m/s, $a = 0$. (b) Constant acceleration $a = +5$ m/s², speeding up. (c) Constant acceleration $a = -5$ m/s², slowing down.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Horizontal = uniform motion. Sloped line = constant acceleration. Slope direction indicates acceleration sign.

worked_examples.title: Free Fall Graph
worked_examples.problem: A ball is dropped from rest. Sketch its velocity-time graph for the first 3 seconds (take downward as negative, $g = -10$ m/s²).

step_by_step.explanation: Dropped from rest: $v_i = 0$ at $t = 0$
Free fall: $a = -10$ m/s² (constant downward)
Straight line from $(0, 0)$ to $(3, -30)$. Negative slope (downward sloping), below horizontal axis (negative velocity). Slope = -10 m/s².

worked_examples.final_answer: Straight line sloping downward from origin to $(3 \text{ s}, -30 \text{ m/s})$. Constant negative slope = constant downward acceleration.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant acceleration produces straight sloped line. Negative acceleration = negative slope. Starting from rest: line begins at origin.

image.alt: Collection of velocity-time graphs showing different motion types
image.caption: Graph shapes: horizontal = uniform motion, sloped = constant acceleration, crossing axis = direction reversal

sections.introduction: Position-time and velocity-time graphs show the same motion from different perspectives. Understanding how they relate deepens comprehension.

key_concept.definition: The two graph types are connected by calculus relationships: velocity is the slope of position-time graph, and displacement is the area under velocity-time graph. Visually: steep x-t graph ↔ high v-t graph; flat x-t graph ↔ zero v-t graph; curved x-t graph ↔ sloped v-t graph.
key_concept.context: Given one graph, you can construct or interpret the other. This dual representation provides complementary insights into motion.

classifications.value: How features translate between graph types

examples.process: x-t horizontal line (flat) ↔ v-t on axis (v=0)
examples.explanation: No position change → zero velocity

examples.process: x-t upward straight line ↔ v-t horizontal line above axis
examples.explanation: Constant positive slope → constant positive velocity

examples.process: x-t downward straight line ↔ v-t horizontal line below axis
examples.explanation: Constant negative slope → constant negative velocity

examples.process: x-t upward curve (steepening) ↔ v-t upward sloped line
examples.explanation: Increasing slope → increasing velocity → positive acceleration

examples.process: x-t upward curve (flattening) ↔ v-t downward sloped line
examples.explanation: Decreasing slope → decreasing velocity → negative acceleration

examples.process: x-t parabola (peak) ↔ v-t line crossing axis
examples.explanation: Position reaches maximum then decreases → velocity goes positive, zero at peak, then negative

worked_examples.title: Converting x-t to v-t Graph
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows: (1) $t = 0$ to $t = 4$ s: straight line, slope = +5 m/s, (2) $t = 4$ to $t = 7$ s: horizontal line, (3) $t = 7$ to $t = 10$ s: straight line, slope = -3 m/s. Sketch the corresponding velocity-time graph.

step_by_step.explanation: x-t slope = +5 m/s → v = +5 m/s. Draw horizontal line at $v = +5$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 4$ s.
x-t horizontal → slope = 0 → v = 0 m/s. Draw horizontal line at $v = 0$ from $t = 4$ to $t = 7$ s.
x-t slope = -3 m/s → v = -3 m/s. Draw horizontal line at $v = -3$ m/s from $t = 7$ to $t = 10$ s.
Three horizontal segments at different heights: +5, 0, -3 m/s. Step-like appearance.

worked_examples.final_answer: v-t graph with three horizontal segments: $v = +5$ m/s (0-4s), $v = 0$ (4-7s), $v = -3$ m/s (7-10s)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope of x-t graph = height of v-t graph. Constant x-t slope → horizontal v-t line at that velocity.

worked_examples.title: Converting v-t to x-t Graph Concept
worked_examples.problem: A v-t graph shows constant $v = 10$ m/s from $t = 0$ to $t = 5$ s. If object starts at $x_i = 0$, describe the x-t graph.

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line → constant velocity → uniform motion → zero acceleration
Constant velocity → x-t graph is straight line with constant slope
Slope = velocity = +10 m/s. Intercept = $x_i = 0$ m. Equation: $x = 0 + 10t = 10t$
Straight line from $(0, 0)$ to $(5, 50)$. Upward sloping at steady rate.

worked_examples.final_answer: x-t graph is straight line from origin to $(5 \text{ s}, 50 \text{ m})$, slope = +10 m/s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant v-t height → straight x-t line with slope = that velocity.

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Several common errors occur when working with velocity-time graphs. Awareness helps prevent these mistakes.

categories.type: Mistake: Confusing v-t with x-t Graphs

examples.explanation: Looking at v-t graph and thinking height shows position instead of velocity.
Always check axis labels. v-t graph: vertical axis = velocity. x-t graph: vertical axis = position. Different information!

categories.type: Mistake: Thinking Higher Means Faster Moving

examples.explanation: Seeing v-t line higher than another and thinking it means 'ahead' or 'farther.'
Higher on v-t graph means greater velocity (moving faster), not farther traveled. Displacement depends on area, not height.

categories.type: Mistake: Forgetting Sign for Area Below Axis
categories.description: Calculating area below axis as positive.

examples.explanation: Area below axis = 20 m, treating as +20 m displacement
Below axis → negative velocity → negative displacement. Area = -20 m.

categories.type: Mistake: Not Squaring Units for Acceleration

examples.explanation: Slope = 5 m/s (missing one '/s')
Acceleration units: m/s². Slope = 5 m/s²

categories.type: Mistake: Thinking Slope on v-t Means Velocity
categories.description: Confusing which quantity the slope represents.

examples.explanation: Slope of v-t graph = velocity (NO!)
Slope of v-t graph = acceleration. Height of v-t graph = velocity.

summary: Velocity-time graphs plot velocity (vertical axis) versus time (horizontal axis), directly showing how velocity changes over time. Two critical relationships: (1) slope of v-t graph equals acceleration ($a = \Delta v / \Delta t = \text{slope}$), and (2) area under v-t curve equals displacement ($\Delta x = \text{area}$). Graph interpretation: horizontal line indicates constant velocity (uniform motion, zero acceleration), sloped straight line indicates constant acceleration (uniformly accelerated motion), positive slope indicates positive acceleration (velocity increasing if positive, or decreasing if negative), negative slope indicates negative acceleration (velocity decreasing if positive, or increasing magnitude if negative). The steeper the slope, the greater the acceleration. To calculate acceleration: find slope using any two points: $a = (v_2 - v_1)/(t_2 - t_1)$. Include units: m/s². To calculate displacement: find area under curve between curve and horizontal axis. For rectangles: area = base × height = $\Delta t \times v$. For triangles: area = $\frac{1}{2}$ base × height. For trapezoids: area = $\frac{1}{2}(v_1 + v_2) \times \Delta t$. Areas above horizontal axis are positive displacement (positive direction); areas below are negative displacement (negative direction). Total displacement = sum of signed areas. For multi-segment motion: sum areas of all segments. Line crossing horizontal axis indicates direction reversal (velocity changes sign, passes through zero). Velocity-time graphs connect to position-time graphs: slope of x-t graph = height of v-t graph (velocity), curvature of x-t graph relates to slope of v-t graph (acceleration), area under v-t curve = change in position shown on x-t graph. Understanding both graph types provides complete picture of motion: x-t graphs show where object is, v-t graphs show how fast and which direction it's moving.
